15 liquid hydrogens, by my calculations.

15 liquid hydrogens, by my calculations.

Did you take the Coriolis effect into account? I only make it 12 liquid hydrogens.

It's not a comprehensive comparison, but here's the DIV-Heavy next to some other launchers for size comparison:

http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/media/180812/Comparative-diagram-of-eight-launch-vehicles-V-2-R-7

Of currently flying launchers, the Ariane 5 probably comes closest to being able to do this mission (DIV-heavy 28,000kg to LEO versus 21,000 for Ariane-5) - the Russian Proton is slightly less than Ariane.

Falcon heavy (as spec'd on paper) could most certainly do it (53,000 kg) and of course the SLS will one day hopefully send this thing around the Moon. There's probably also some paper rockets from China and Russia that could do it as well. The Angara A7 variant lists 35 tons as its LEO target, which translates to 31,700 kgs, roughly. The heaviest Chinese Long March 5 variant seems to be about 25t which is only about 22,000 kg.

And of course Energia could have done it, 100,000 kg to LEO. But that would have been silly.

15 liquid hydrogens, by my calculations.

Arbitrary units are the best units because your answer is always correct.
